fields.name: San Diego State University
fields.about:
San Diego State University (SDSU): Overview, Rankings & Achievements

History & Accreditations
Founded in 1897 as San Diego Normal School, SDSU is the third-oldest institution in the California State University system. From its original 17-acre site, it has grown into a major public research university, federally designated as a Hispanic-Serving and AANAPISI institution. SDSU is accredited by the AACSB, ACBSP, and WASC.

Rankings
SDSU consistently ranks among the top public universities:

#148 nationally – U.S. News & World Report (2022)

#152 – Times Higher Education (2022)

#181 – Forbes (2019-20)

Campus & Facilities
Spanning 288 acres in central San Diego, SDSU features modern labs, residence halls, and the award-winning Conrad Prebys Aztec Student Union (LEED Platinum certified). The Parma Payne Goodall Alumni Center hosts regional events, and seven campus buildings are listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

The ongoing SDSU Mission Valley development expands educational and research spaces with new housing, retail, transit options, and a 34-acre River Park.

Academic Offerings
SDSU offers 190 undergraduate, 91 postgraduate, and 20+ doctoral programs across liberal arts, vocational colleges, and specialized schools like the L. Robert Payne School of Hospitality & Tourism Management and the Charles W. Lamden School of Accountancy.

Notable Achievements & Alumni
A top CSU campus for federal research funding, SDSU has received over $190 million in grants. It was the first U.S. university to offer a Women’s Studies course and an MBA in Global Entrepreneurship across four international institutions. Over 40 students have been named Fulbright Scholars since 2005.

Notable alumni include:

Ellen Ochoa – Former astronaut and engineer

Kathleen Kennedy – President, Lucasfilm

Courtney Friel – Fox News anchor

Gen. Merrill McPeak – 14th USAF Chief of Staff

Diversity & Corporate Connections
SDSU ranks among the top 10 U.S. universities for ethnic and racial diversity. International students make up 8.3% of enrollment. The campus is home to students of Asian (7.3%), African American (4%), and Filipino (5.9%) backgrounds.

Top employers include Apple, Qualcomm, Intel, KPMG, Northrop Grumman, Marriott, EY, Microsoft, and the U.S. Navy. The university’s mentoring program has connected 7,000+ students with alumni mentors.

fields.name: Rotterdam School of Management
fields.about:
Erasmus University Rotterdam, located in Rotterdam, Netherlands, is a prestigious and comprehensive institution known for its multicultural environment and innovative teaching methods. The university offers cutting-edge knowledge across a wide range of disciplines, ensuring students receive a top-quality education. It consistently ranks among the top 10 universities globally for medical sciences and business schools according to the Financial Times.

The university places strong emphasis on key social areas such as social health, wealth management, governance, and culture, along with other practical and impactful fields. Erasmus University is dedicated to providing education in leading disciplines, fostering a study-friendly atmosphere that challenges and inspires students.

Students benefit from state-of-the-art facilities, including advanced laboratories, testing fields, chemical research centers, audition and media rooms, as well as extensive training sessions and research workshops. The faculty is highly experienced and well-qualified, offering expert guidance and support to help students overcome challenges and excel beyond textbook knowledge.

Erasmus University Rotterdam is committed to supporting a diverse student body and currently hosts over 5,000 international students. The campus is fully equipped to offer courses in English and various other languages, creating a truly global learning environment. With excellent study spaces, a modern library housing millions of books, and numerous sports and recreational facilities, the campus functions almost like a self-contained mini-city, providing everything students need for both academic and daily life.
fields.admission_requirements:
Application Process for RSM MSc Programmes
Choose your desired MSc programme on the RSM MSc programmes page.

Register in Studielink, the Dutch national student registration system.

Complete the online application form (OLAF) via the RSM application portal.

Upload all required documents during the application.

Submit your application (note: after submission, you cannot edit it).

Respond to admission offer within 14 days (accept, decline, or defer except for MSc International Management/CEMS).

Submit certified copies of final diploma and transcript by August 31 to finalize enrollment.

Documents Required
Final Diploma
Certified copy or official university statement confirming completion if diploma is not yet available.

Transcript of Records
Certified copy of your academic transcript.

Translations
Official translations by a sworn translator if documents are not in English, Dutch, or German.

Proof of English Proficiency
Accepted tests: TOEFL (min. 100), IELTS (min. 7.0), Cambridge C1 Advanced or C2 Proficiency.
Some applicants may be exempt based on nationality or previous education.

GMAT or GRE Scores (if applicable)
Required for non-Dutch academic backgrounds. Submit GMAT/GRE scores as per instructions.

Motivation Statement
Answer three motivation questions in English within the application portal.

Additional Documents (if applicable)
Certified copies of diplomas and transcripts for any additional degrees.
Language proficiency for MSc International Management/CEMS may be required.

fields.name: San Francisco State University
fields.about:
History, Affiliations & Rankings
Founded in 1899 as San Francisco State Normal School, SFSU is a public research university and part of the California State University system. It earned university status in 1972 and is accredited by the Western Association of Schools and Colleges (WASC).

SFSU is ranked:

#121–130 in U.S. Universities – QS Rankings

#401–500 in U.S. College Rankings 2022 – Times Higher Education

#1175 globally – U.S. News & World Report

Located in urban San Francisco, it follows a semester-based academic calendar. Its motto is "Experience Teaches," and its mascot is the Gator.

Campus, Facilities & Programs
The main campus spans 144 acres in southwest San Francisco and includes:

12 academic buildings

8 residence halls

Mashouf Wellness Center (health, recreation, and wellness hub)

Cox Stadium, Maloney Field, and gyms

Additional centers: Romberg Tiburon Center, Sierra Nevada Field Campus, Downtown Campus

SFSU offers:

118 bachelor's, 94 master's, 5 doctoral, and 26 teaching credential programs

Specialized doctoral degrees like the Ed.D., D.P.T., and Ph.D. in Education

There are 200+ student clubs supporting diverse interests and communities.

Research, Achievements & Alumni
SFSU faculty have earned top honors including the Pulitzer Prize, MacArthur Genius Grant, and Guggenheim Award. The university received a $10M NIH grant to support biomedical research and career development. It also offers one of only two MPH programs in the U.S. focused on Urban Health and Social Justice.

Notable alumni include:

Stanley Mazor – Co-inventor of the microprocessor

Annette Bening – Acclaimed actress

Yvonne Cagle – NASA astronaut

Student Diversity & Employers
SFSU enrolls over 26,600 students, with:

23,300 undergraduates

2,900+ postgraduates

2,300+ international students

45:55 male-to-female ratio

Only 2% live in campus housing; most students reside off-campus.

Top recruiters include:
Google, Adobe, Apple, Meta, Microsoft, LinkedIn, Amazon, Tesla, KPMG, PayPal, and others.

fields.name: San Jose State University
fields.about:
San José State University (SJSU), founded in 1857 as Minns Evening Normal School, is the oldest public institution of higher education on the West Coast. It became California State University, San José in 1972 after earning university status, and was officially renamed San José State University in 1974 by the California legislature. A member of the California State University (CSU) system, SJSU is affiliated with the space-grant program and competes in NCAA Division I FBS athletics. In recent years, the university has earned recognition in several rankings, including #1001–1200 in the Times Higher Education World University Rankings (2022) and #22 in U.S. News & World Report’s 2022 list of Regional Universities West.

Located in downtown San José, the university consists of two main areas: the main campus and the south campus. The campus offers a dynamic student experience, with facilities like a 128,000-square-foot Spartan Recreation Center and a 53,000-square-foot student wellness center. SJSU also hosts over 450 student clubs, and traditions such as Weeks of Welcome and Homecoming foster a vibrant campus culture. The Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Library provides extensive academic resources, including printing labs, Wi-Fi access, and collaborative study spaces. Academically, the university offers a wide range of programs—143 undergraduate, 95 graduate, 11 teaching credential, and 38 certificate programs—designed to combine academic rigor with real-world experience.

SJSU is accredited by the WASC Senior College and University Commission and has a strong reputation for research and innovation. In 2019, it secured $44.3 million in research and development funding, making it one of the top CSU campuses in terms of research investment. The university is known for its strong ties to Silicon Valley, serving as a top talent pipeline for major tech companies. Its alumni network includes notable figures such as Lou Henry Hoover, former First Lady of the United States; Helder Antunes, senior executive at Cisco; and Lee P. Brown, former NYPD Commissioner and Mayor of Houston. SJSU is also a leading feeder school for companies like Apple, Facebook, Google, and Oracle.

With over 33,000 students, including approximately 3,200 international students and 2,100 faculty members, SJSU is one of the most diverse institutions in the region. The student body includes 32.5% Asian, 27.1% Hispanic or Latino, 17.6% White, and 3.4% Black or African American students, reflecting a strong commitment to inclusivity. The male-to-female ratio is nearly balanced at 52:48. Top employers recruiting from SJSU include Amazon, Meta, Microsoft, KPMG, and other industry leaders, offering students strong career prospects in a competitive job market.

fields.name: Santa Clara University
fields.about:
Founded in 1777 around the historic Mission Santa Clara de Asís, Santa Clara University (SCU) evolved into a full university by 1912 with the addition of law and engineering programs. The Leavey School of Business, established in 1926, quickly gained national accreditation. Accredited by WASC, SCU ranks #85 in QS US University Rankings and holds strong positions in U.S. News & World Report for national universities, undergraduate teaching, and value.

Located on a 106-acre Silicon Valley campus, SCU blends Jesuit values with innovation. Its facilities include the Mission, 11 residence halls, a large library, performing arts center, TV studio, museum, and athletic complexes. The university offers diverse undergraduate and graduate programs, with popular majors in business, engineering, social sciences, and biomedical sciences.

SCU is recognized for sustainability leadership, earning awards like the AASHE Sustainable Campus Index Top Performer and Princeton Review’s Top 50 Green Schools. It boasts a global alumni network of over 103,000, including notable figures such as NBA star Steve Nash, former California Governor Jerry Brown, and U.S. Representative Zoe Lofgren.

With 8,669 students—nearly half identifying as people of color—and an even gender split, most undergraduates come from California and 27 other countries. The university’s career services connect students with top employers like Google, Apple, Amazon, Cisco, Oracle, and Microsoft.

fields.name: Rowan University
fields.about:
Rowan University Overview

History & Rankings:
Founded in 1923 to train teachers for South Jersey, Rowan University has grown into a respected public research institution. It competes in NCAA Division III (NJAC) and holds notable rankings, including #179 National Universities and #88 Top Public Schools by U.S. News & World Report 2022.

Campuses & Programs:
Rowan operates multiple campuses in Glassboro, Camden, and Stratford, NJ. It houses various research centers like the Geospatial Research Lab and the NeuroMusculoskeletal Institute. With over 19,600 students, it offers 85 bachelor’s, 46 master’s, 2 professional, and 6 doctoral programs across 13 colleges, including engineering, business, medicine, and the arts.

Achievements & Alumni:
Recognized as one of the best public universities in the North, Rowan is unique in having two medical schools. Its 82,000+ alumni include notable figures such as wrestler Nick Comoroto and Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist Trymaine Lee. Alumni benefit from free access to campus facilities and events.

Diversity & Career Opportunities:
Rowan’s student body is 31% minority with 64.8% White students. The university hosts an annual career fair attended by 150 employers, including Lockheed Martin, Boeing, and Disney. Graduates start with an average salary of $70,000.

fields.name: Royal Roads University
fields.about:
History, Affiliations, and Rankings
Royal Roads University, established in 1995 in Colwood, British Columbia, is a public research university focused on lifelong learning. It operates on the site of the former Royal Roads Military College and offers professional degrees. The university is affiliated with organizations such as the International Association of Universities, Universities Canada, and the Canadian Virtual University.

Campus, Infrastructure, and Programs
The campus spans 565 acres of scenic parkland featuring trails, gardens, and historic buildings. Royal Roads emphasizes sustainability in all activities. It offers applied undergraduate, graduate, and doctoral programs mainly in a blended format, combining online courses with short on-campus residencies held locally or internationally.

Achievements and Alumni
With over 20,000 graduates worldwide, Royal Roads maintains close ties with the Canadian Forces and the Royal Roads Military College alumni community. Notable alumni include leadership and business figures like Grad Wasan Jema and Gordon Exel. The university also hosts the Royal Roads Military College Museum.

Diversity and Student Life
Home to more than 5,300 students from over 60 countries, including 550 international students, Royal Roads fosters an inclusive and diverse community. Small class sizes (average 25) and a 12:1 student-faculty ratio allow personalized learning experiences.

fields.name: Rutgers University
fields.about:
History, Affiliations & Rankings
Founded in 1766 as Queen's College, Rutgers University is one of the oldest and most prestigious public research universities in the U.S. Renamed in 1825 to honor Colonel Henry Rutgers, it is now New Jersey’s largest public university and a land-, sea-, and space-grant institution. Rutgers is accredited by the Middle States Commission on Higher Education and is a member of the Association of American Universities. It ranked #751–800 in the QS World University Rankings 2021 and #166 in the Times Higher Education Rankings.

Campuses, Infrastructure & Programs
Rutgers operates across three main campuses: New Brunswick (its largest), Newark, and Camden. The historic New Brunswick campus spans six towns and includes notable landmarks like Old Queens and Voorhees Mall. The university offers over 150 undergraduate minors and 400+ graduate and professional programs. Annual tuition ranges from $33,000 to $46,000 including room and board, with a $70 non-refundable application fee.

Achievements & Alumni
A pioneer in U.S. college sports, Rutgers played the first intercollegiate football game. The university boasts more than 140 alumni chapters globally and has produced leaders in law, science, education, and business. Notable alumni include author Junot Díaz, former FBI Director Louis Freeh, and ESPN founder Bill Rasmussen. Several Rutgers athletic teams have earned NCAA academic honors.

Diversity & Employers
Rutgers enrolls over 76,000 students across all campuses, including more than 9,000 international students from 130+ countries. At New Brunswick, the student body is 36.4% White, 25.9% Asian, 12.8% Hispanic, and 7.7% Black. Graduates are recruited by top employers across sectors, thanks to the university’s strong academic and research reputation.

fields.name: RWTH Aachen University
fields.about:
History, Affiliations, and Rankings
RWTH Aachen University, founded in 1858 in Aachen, Germany, is a top technical university with strong ties to both national and international research organizations. It’s accredited by the AACSB and linked to groups like the German Research Foundation and the European Universities Association. RWTH ranks #165 globally (QS), #108 (THE), and #192 (US News).

Campus, Facilities, and Programs
The university’s campus covers over 620 acres across Aachen, with key buildings near the city center, including the Main Building and SuperC student center. RWTH offers 10 faculties, including Engineering, Medicine, Business, and Humanities.

Achievements and Alumni
RWTH was named a German University of Excellence in 2007 and continues to receive top funding. Notable alumni include Nobel laureate Peter Debye and former Indonesian President B.J. Habibie.

Student Diversity and Career Support
Over 26% of RWTH’s 46,000+ students are international, representing 100+ countries. The university promotes diversity, inclusion, and gender equality. Its Career Service Centre offers support through career fairs and employer connections.

fields.name: Tallinn University
fields.about:
Tallinn University: Overview
History & Rankings
Founded in 1919 as Tallinn Teachers’ Seminar, Tallinn University became its current form in 2005 after merging several institutions in the capital city of Estonia. It's a public research university and a member of EUA and UNICA. It ranked #1230 in U.S. News and placed in the 1001–1200 band in both QS and Times Higher Education rankings (2022).

Campus & Academics
Located on a 135-acre campus in Tallinn, the university includes academic buildings, a science park, sports complex, and housing. In 2015, it restructured into six schools to streamline research and teaching. It offers 30 bachelor’s, 50 master’s, and 10 doctoral programs across fields like humanities, digital technologies, health sciences, media, and education. Core focus areas include sustainable lifestyles, digital culture, governance, educational innovation, and cultural competence.

Achievements & Alumni
Tallinn University is part of UNICA’s Green Academic Footprint and is known for its work in education innovation, e-governance, and entrepreneurship. Distinguished alumni include philosopher Andres Luure, politician Mihhail Lotman, and filmmaker Pia Tikka.

Student Life & Careers
With over 7,000 students, including about 9.5% international students, Tallinn University promotes a diverse and inclusive campus. Student clubs and sports councils foster community life. Top companies like Skype, Wise, Telia, and Swedbank regularly recruit graduates.

fields.name: Tampere University
fields.about:
Tampere University: Overview
Founded in 1925 as the Civic College in Helsinki, Tampere University adopted its current name in 1966. It's a member of several international academic networks, including the European Consortium of Innovative Universities and EUA. It ranks globally at 414 (QS), 251–300 (THE), and 354 (US News).

Campus & Academics
Located in Kalevanharju, the university has seven faculties, ranging from Medicine and Health Technology to Information Technology and Social Sciences. Key facilities include a Language Centre, Library, Teaching School, and Tampere University Hospital.

Achievements & Alumni
Tampere University is one of Finland’s most multidisciplinary institutions, producing around 3,600 scientific publications annually. Notable alumni include former Finnish Prime Ministers Jyrki Katainen and Sanna Marin, and Finance Minister Mika Lintilä.

Student Life & Opportunities
With over 1,000 international exchange students yearly and 550+ global partnerships, Tampere offers rich international exposure. Its career services and regular job fairs help students connect with employers and gain practical experience.

fields.name: Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv
fields.about:
Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv

History & Rankings:
Founded in 1834 as the Kyiv Imperial Institute of Saint Vladimir, the university is now named after the poet Taras Shevchenko. Located in Kyiv, Ukraine, it’s affiliated with the International Association of Universities and the European University Association. It ranks #651–700 in the 2023 QS World University Rankings.

Campus & Academics:
The main campus at 60 Vladimirska Street includes notable buildings like the Red Building, Botanical Gardens, and Maksymovych Library. The university has 15 faculties and 5 schools offering programs in fields such as Accounting, Geography, IT, and History.

Achievements & Alumni:
The university has received multiple national awards and honors. Notable alumni include sociologist Iryna Bekeshkina, musicologist Yurii Chekan, and geneticist Theodosius Dobzhansky.

Student Body & Industry Connections:
With around 30,000 students—including 2,000 international—and 3,000 faculty, the university fosters a diverse community. Partner companies include EY, Sanity Desk, FastLane, and UniCredit.

fields.name: Tbilisi State Medical University
fields.about:
Tbilisi State Medical University (TSMU) Overview

History & Rankings
Established in 1918 by Ivane Javakhishvili, TSMU was the first university of its kind in the Caucasus. It operates from a historic building originally designed for the Georgian Nobility Gymnasium. TSMU is recognized by WHO, the European Commission of Education, WFME, and is a member of IAU and EUA. It ranks #571–580 in the QS World University Rankings 2022.

Campus & Academics
Located in the welcoming city of Tbilisi, the university offers modern classrooms, well-equipped libraries, and advanced labs. TSMU provides bachelor's, master's, and doctoral programs, with several medical degrees taught in English—including the American MD Program, Pharmacy, Physical Medicine & Rehabilitation, and Certified Stomatology programs.

Recognition & Alumni
Degrees from TSMU are recognized by the MCI (India), ECFMG (USA), and other global bodies. The university follows the EU Bologna Process. Notable alumni include former Georgian Prime Ministers Giorgi Gakharia and Giorgi Arsenishvili, philosopher Kiwi Margwelaschwili, and linguist Arnold Chikobava.

Student Life & Diversity
With over 10,000 students—including 25% international students from India, Ghana, Iraq, Germany, and beyond—TSMU is a global hub for medical education. It ranks among the top medical universities in Georgia and maintains partnerships with reputed companies for student placements.

fields.name: Technical University Dortmund
fields.about:
TU Dortmund University: Overview

History & Rankings
Founded in 1968 during the Ruhr region's shift from heavy industry to technology, TU Dortmund played a key role in economic transformation. It's part of the University Alliance Ruhr (UA Ruhr) and ranks #525 in Best Global Universities.

Campus & Academics
The university has 16 faculties spanning engineering, science, social sciences, and cultural studies. It offers over 190 bachelor's and master's programs. Key facilities include research centers, teacher training institutes, and the German Institute for Civic Art. The campus is split into North and South sections, both located near Dortmund city center.

Notable Alumni & Achievements
TU Dortmund is known for strong academic support and a robust advisory system. Prominent alumni include former German President Johannes Rau, European Council President Donald Tusk, and politician Carsten Brosda.

Student Life & Career Opportunities
With a diverse student body, TU Dortmund fosters a global academic environment. Leading companies such as Google, Microsoft, American Express, and Financial Times recruit from the university.

fields.name: Technical University of Braunschweig
fields.about: The Technical University of Braunschweig (TU Braunschweig), founded in 1745 as Collegium Carolinum, is a member of TU9, a group of Germany’s top research universities. It comprises six main faculties: Life Sciences; Mechanical Engineering; Humanities & Educational Sciences; Architecture, Civil Engineering & Environmental Sciences; Electrical Engineering, Information Technology, and Physics; and the Carl Friedrich Gauss Faculty. TU Braunschweig hosts many events celebrating cultural diversity and international exchange. Known as an open and research-focused university, it attracts students and researchers worldwide. The university maintains strong global partnerships with institutions across South America, Canada, Indonesia, the USA, Japan, and Europe.

fields.name: Technical University of Darmstadt
fields.about:
Founded in 1877, Technische Universität Darmstadt, also known as Darmstadt University of Technology, is a public research university. The university initially launched its Electrical Engineering program and has since expanded its curriculum to include a wide range of advanced subjects. The campus spans over 600 acres and is divided into two main areas. The inner-city campus hosts departments such as Information Technology, Electrical Engineering, Human Sciences, History, Social Science, Mathematics, Computer Science, Law, and Economics. The Lichtwiese campus is home to the Departments of Geodesy, Mechanical Engineering, Architecture, and Earth Sciences.

The university serves approximately 26,360 students and employs around 2,756 staff members. Several renowned research centers are located on campus, including the Center for Heavy Ion Research, the Institute for Secure Information Technology, the Center for Computer Graphics Research, and the Space Operations Center.

TUD boasts a distinguished list of alumni, such as Günter Behnisch, the architect of the Munich Olympic Stadium; Kurt H. Debus, a pioneering rocket scientist; Paul Friedlander, a noted chemist; and Gerhard Hennige, an Olympic medalist.

fields.name: Technical University of Denmark
fields.about:
History, Affiliations, and Rankings
Founded in 1829 by H.C. Ørsted, the Technical University of Denmark (DTU) is a top international university specializing in technology and natural sciences with a strong business focus. It is affiliated with the European Universities Association, CESAER, and EuroTech Universities Alliance. DTU ranks 99th in QS World University Rankings 2022 and 185th in Times Higher Education 2022, making it a popular choice for engineering studies.

Campuses and Courses
DTU has four campuses: Lyngby, Ballerup, Rise (Roskilde), and Sisimiut (Greenland). The Lyngby campus features 100 academic buildings amid green surroundings, while Rise spans 262 hectares. With over 20 departments, DTU offers diverse undergraduate engineering programs, 25 master’s degrees, Ph.D. programs, and international joint degrees with partner universities across Scandinavia, Europe, and Asia.

Research, Alumni, and Innovation
DTU leads Denmark in research with 1,700+ industry projects, 62 commercialized inventions, and 55 start-ups. Its publications rank among Europe’s top 10%. Accredited by the Danish Accreditation Institution, DTU’s notable alumni include Nobel laureates Henrik Pontoppidan and Henrik Dam, mathematician Johan Jensen, and Olympian Harald Bohr. DTU ranks #2 in World University Research Rankings.

Student Diversity and Industry Links
DTU hosts over 11,200 students, including 2,000 international students from 107+ countries, with 37% women. The inclusive campus supports diverse backgrounds and accessibility needs. Strong industry ties with companies like Bioneer Ltd. and DTU Science Park offer extensive recruitment and innovation opportunities.

fields.name: Technical University of Dresden
fields.about:
History, Affiliations, and Rankings
Founded in 1828 as the Technische Bildungsanstalt in Dresden, TU Dresden evolved into a full university by 1961. It’s accredited by the Saxon Ministry of Science and Art and part of prestigious groups like PEGASUS, T.I.M.E., and CESAER. TU Dresden ranks #194 in QS World University Rankings and holds strong positions in U.S. News global and European university lists.

Campus and Courses
The main campus, south of Dresden city center, features buildings from 1890, post-war, and modern eras. TU Dresden is a comprehensive university with 17 faculties, including Natural Sciences, Engineering, Humanities, Medicine, and Teacher Training.

Achievements and Alumni
TU Dresden is recognized for excellent research and diverse academic programs, earning "University of Excellence" status in Germany. It’s a TU9 member, Germany’s elite tech universities group. Notable alumni include Berlin senator Katja Kipping, mathematician Maria Reiche, and Fraunhofer Society president Reimund Neugebauer.

Student Body and Industry Connections
With over 30,000 students—16% international—the university fosters a diverse community. The Career Service supports students’ professional growth. Top employers of graduates include BMW, Bosch, Volkswagen, Accenture, Deloitte, and Amazon.

fields.name: Technical University of Munich
fields.about:
History, Affiliations, and Rankings
Founded in 1868 by King Ludwig II, the Technical University of Munich (TUM) is a leading German university and a member of the prestigious TU9 group. Initially called the University of Excellence, it adopted its current name in 1970. TUM helped transform Bavaria from an agricultural to an industrial region. It’s accredited by the Swiss Center for Accreditation and ranks #50 (QS), #38 (THE), and #74 (US News) globally.

Campuses and Courses
TUM has three campuses around Munich. The central Munich campus hosts faculties like Electrical Engineering, Architecture, Economics, and Medicine. The Garching campus focuses on Mathematics, Chemistry, Physics, and Mechanical Engineering. The Weihenstephan campus offers programs in Biology, Brewing, Forestry, Agriculture, and Nutrition. TUM emphasizes interdisciplinary research, including life sciences and biotechnology.

Achievements and Alumni
With over 150 years of history, TUM is among Europe’s top universities and a German University of Excellence. It has produced 17 Nobel laureates and numerous prestigious awards. The university has generated 211 inventions, 73 patents, and launched 75 startups. Notable alumni include Rudolf Diesel, Oskar von Miller, and Nobel winner Joachim Frank.

Student Diversity and Career Support
TUM values diversity and inclusion across gender, ethnicity, age, and ability. It educates over 48,000 students, with 38% international and 36% female enrollment. The university offers extensive career services, including job portals, newsletters, application guides, CV checks, and counseling to support students and alumni.

fields.name: Technische Hochschule Ingolstadt
fields.about:
History, Affiliations, and Rankings
Founded in 1994 with just 90 students and 3 professors, Ingolstadt University of Applied Sciences (THI) began at Hohe Schule in Ingolstadt. In 1999, it moved to its current Esplanade campus. THI is affiliated with Bayerisches Foresight-Institut, CARISSMA (automated driving research), AImotion Bavaria, THI Business School, and the Center for Applied Research (IAF).

Campus, Facilities, and Courses
The Esplanade campus spans 15 acres near downtown Ingolstadt and features libraries, labs, lecture halls, and workshops. THI offers over 60 programs through five faculties:

Electrical Engineering & IT

Computer Science

Mechanical Engineering

Engineering & Management

THI Business School

It also offers dual study options combining academic learning with vocational training and hands-on industry experience.

Achievements and Alumni
THI has 200+ academic and industry partners and a €20 million research budget. Its research is featured in the HRK Research Map for German universities. Notable alumni include poet Jakob Balde and author Thomas Wensing.

Student Body and Recruiters
With over 6,000 students, including 600 in dual study programs and 100 PhD candidates, THI draws a diverse international population. Around 200 professors support academic programs. Companies like Audi and Mercedes Bank regularly recruit from the university.

fields.name: Sapienza University
fields.about:
History, Rankings, and Affiliations
Founded by Pope Boniface VIII in 1303, Sapienza University of Rome is one of the oldest universities in the world. Located in Italy’s capital, it has played a vital role in the country's academic, political, and cultural evolution. Known for its strong research focus and commitment to accessible, high-quality education, Sapienza ranked #197 in the Times Higher Education World University Rankings 2022.

Campus, Infrastructure, and Academics
Sapienza’s main campus, Città Universitaria, spans 110 acres near Roma Tiburtina Station. It features 54 libraries, 18 museums, tutoring services, student support offices, and eco-conscious initiatives. The university offers over 280 degree programs (including 35+ in English), 200 vocational master's, and nearly 80 PhD programs. Research spans disciplines such as physics, astrophysics, humanities, and nanotechnology. Scholarships and elite programs, like the School of Advanced Studies, support top-performing students. Each year, over 1,100 students participate in international exchange programs.

Achievements and Alumni
Sapienza ranked first globally in Classics and Ancient History in 2018. Distinguished alumni include Nobel laureates, European Commissioners, and scholars such as Benedetto Castelli, Paola S. Timiras, Anna Maria Bisi, and Giuseppe Ungaretti.

Student Body and Recruitment
Home to over 112,000 students and 8,000 staff, Sapienza welcomes around 30,000 new students annually from Italy and abroad. The university encourages cultural and extracurricular engagement. Graduates are recruited by top organizations like Accenture, Deloitte, Enel, EY, Amazon, and the European Commission.

fields.name: Ted Rogers School of Management
fields.about:
Toronto Metropolitan University (formerly Ryerson University) is located in downtown Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Established in 1948 as the Ryerson Institute of Technology, the university has since evolved through several name changes before adopting its most recent title.

The university is situated in the heart of Toronto, close to major attractions such as Kensington Market, Chinatown, and Yonge-Dundas Square. It operates a single, centralized campus covering 121 acres.

TMU offers around 40 academic programs and is home to the well-known Ted Rogers School of Management, considered one of Canada’s top undergraduate business schools. The university's endowment stands at approximately CAD 125 million.

The Ryerson Rams represent the university in various sports. The Ryerson University Library houses over 500,000 physical books, 3,700 printed journals, and electronic resources valued at over CAD 2 million.

Despite its offerings, the university has a highly competitive acceptance rate of just 4% for international students, making admission very selective. Currently, there are over 10,000 students, including around 1,499 international students.

Estimated annual costs for housing and meals are approximately INR 5.6 lakhs. Students can find more information on the official university website.

The university’s motto, "Mente et Artificio," translates to "With Mind and Skill."
fields.admission_requirements:
Application Process
For Undergraduate Programs:
Visit the Ontario Universities' Application Centre (OUAC) website.

Choose your TRSM undergraduate program (e.g., Business Management, Accounting & Finance).

Submit your academic transcripts (Grade 12/U or M level courses).

Pay the application fee (approx. CAD 90).

Upload English proficiency test scores (if required).

Submit any additional materials (depending on program).

Track your application status via the TMU portal.

For Graduate Programs (MBA, MScM, etc.):
Apply through the TMU Graduate Application Portal.

Pay the application fee (CAD 110 for MScM, CAD 150 for MBA).

Submit your academic transcripts (Bachelor’s degree – 4 years).

Upload your resume/CV (MBA applicants need minimum 2 years of experience).

Submit your statement of interest or research proposal.

Provide 2 letters of recommendation (academic or professional).

Upload English proficiency test scores (if applicable).

Complete Kira Talent interview (MBA only).

Monitor updates via your MyServiceHub account.

Documents Required
For All Applicants:
Academic transcripts and certificates

English language proficiency test scores (IELTS/TOEFL/PTE)

Passport copy

Statement of Purpose or Letter of Intent

Curriculum Vitae (CV) or Resume

Letters of Recommendation (usually 2)

Visa/Study permit (after admission)

Application fee payment confirmation

fields.name: Saskatchewan Polytechnic
fields.about:
History, Affiliations, and Rankings
Saskatchewan Polytechnic was formed by merging four institutions established between 1959 and 1986. In 1988, these schools combined under the Saskatchewan Institute of Applied Science and Technology (SIAST), which was renamed Saskatchewan Polytechnic in 2014. The polytechnic partners with organizations like Polytechnics Canada, University of Saskatchewan, University of Regina, and First Nations University of Canada. Its engineering programs are nationally accredited by Technology Accreditation Canada (TAC).

Campuses, Infrastructure, and Courses
Saskatchewan Polytechnic has four campuses: Saskatoon (main), Moose Jaw, Prince Albert, and Regina, each equipped with gyms, labs, libraries, eateries, and bookstores. It offers a wide range of skill-focused programs for local and international students, including Agricultural Equipment Technician, Bachelor of Applied Management, Construction Management, and Information Systems. Popular courses include Dental Hygiene, Medical Radiologic Technology, and Practical Nursing. Most programs integrate hands-on learning with work or field experience.

Accomplishments and Alumni
As Saskatchewan’s leading polytechnic, the institution emphasizes applied, technical, and market-driven education. It supports innovation and skills development to meet industry needs. Its alumni network exceeds 150,000, including notable graduates like Heather Kosowan (Brandt Group) and Danielle Lane (Accenture).

Student Diversity and Employers
With around 6,500 international students across campuses, Saskatchewan Polytechnic fosters a diverse and inclusive community. Major employers recruiting on campus include Accenture, Infosys, Wipro, and Nestlé.

fields.name: Temple University
fields.about:
History, Affiliations & Rankings
Temple University was founded in 1884 by Russell Conwell, who began teaching night classes for working adults in Philadelphia. It officially became “The Temple College” in 1888, aiming to provide education to motivated students from all backgrounds. Temple is affiliated with the Coalition of Urban and Metropolitan Universities (CUMU) and is part of the Space Grant Consortium. It ranks #751-800 in the QS World University Rankings 2022.

Campuses & Programs
Temple has eight campuses, including its lively main campus in Philadelphia, as well as locations in Ambler, Centre City, Harrisburg, Japan, and Rome. The university offers programs through 17 schools and colleges, providing a broad range of courses to meet diverse student needs.

Achievements & Alumni
Temple earned the prestigious R1 Carnegie Classification for research in 2015. It boasts over 340,000 alumni worldwide, including notable figures like actor Bob Saget, actor Kunal Nayyar, and musician John Oates. Recent achievements include Rhodes and Goldwater scholars and its largest graduating class.

Diversity & Industry Connections
Nearly 45% of the Class of 2025 are students of color, with significant increases in Black and Hispanic/Latinx enrollment—the largest in decades. Employers recruiting at Temple include JPMorgan Chase, Johnson & Johnson, Amazon, Deloitte, Microsoft, and Google.

fields.name: Sault College
fields.about:
Sault College of Applied Arts and Technology is a well-known government-funded college located in Ontario, Canada. Situated in a peaceful suburban area, the campus spans a large, serene space. Established in 1965, the college has a strong reputation in arts and technology and has nurtured many industry leaders.

Each year, Sault College admits over 4,000 students, supported by a favorable student-to-teacher ratio of 17:1. The college employs around 700 teaching staff and 200 administrative personnel, reflecting its commitment to quality education.

fields.name: Texas A & M University
fields.about:
History, Affiliations, and Rankings
Founded in 1876 as the Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas, Texas A&M was the state’s first university and is uniquely designated as a Land-, Sea-, and Space-grant institution. Originally admitting only White male students, it became fully integrated in the 1960s. Texas A&M is affiliated with Oak Ridge Associated Universities and the Universities Research Association and joined the Association of American Universities in 2001. It ranks #193 globally (Times Higher Education) and #140 in US News’ Best Global Universities (2022).

Campus and Academics
The main campus in College Station is centrally located within the Houston-Dallas-Austin triangle, serving most of Texas’s population. Branch campuses include Galveston and Qatar, plus specialized centers like the Law School and Health Science Center. Texas A&M offers over 130 undergraduate and 260 graduate/professional degrees through 17 schools and colleges, covering fields such as Engineering, Business, Medicine, Agriculture, Law, and more.

Achievements and Alumni
Texas A&M is among the largest US universities and ranks #1 nationally for affordable, quality education (Fiske Guide) and best value (Money Magazine). It leads Texas in research expenditures, exceeding $1 billion annually, and is #2 in job placement for graduates (Wall Street Journal). The university boasts a network of over 500,000 alumni, including Nobel laureates and notable figures like NBA player Khris Middleton, Olympic athlete Athing Mu, and former Texas governor Rick Perry.

Student Diversity and Employers
With nearly 73,300 students, including 5,100+ internationals from 130+ countries, Texas A&M offers a vibrant campus life with over 1,000 student organizations. Women make up 47% of the population, and the university is known for its “Aggie” spirit. Top employers recruiting Aggies include Amazon, Microsoft, Apple, Tesla, Chevron, and Meta.

fields.name: Sciences Po
fields.about:
History, Affiliations, and Rankings
Sciences Po, formally the Paris Institute of Political Studies, was founded in 1872 to strengthen France’s political and diplomatic leadership. It is linked with Sorbonne Paris Cité, APSIA, COUPERIN, and CGE. According to QS World University Rankings 2022, it ranks #261 globally.

Campuses, Courses, and Programs
With seven campuses across France, each focusing on a different global region, Sciences Po offers a broad education in humanities and social sciences. It provides around 30 Master’s degrees and Ph.D. programs in law, economics, history, political science, sociology, and more, supported by 11 research institutes. The school hosts the annual MiniCrit event, featuring sports and arts competitions among campuses.

Accomplishments and Alumni
Known as an elite “school of power,” Sciences Po fosters connections with influential networks in French society. To promote diversity, it launched the Equal Opportunity Programme in 2001. The alumni network includes over 55,000 graduates, including notable figures like Nebahat Albayrak (Dutch politician), Božidar ?eli? (Serbian VP), and singer Camille.

Student Diversity and Experience
Sciences Po’s student body represents 150+ countries, with nearly half being international. Undergraduates have the opportunity for a year abroad to broaden their global outlook. The School of Public Affairs trains socially responsible future leaders and policymakers.

fields.name: Texas Christian University
fields.about:
History, Affiliations, and Rankings
Founded in 1873 by the Clark brothers in Texas, USA, Texas Christian University (TCU) was originally named AddRan Christian University. The institution’s primary mission was to promote classical education and leadership development among its students. It was notably the first coeducational university in West Mississippi. In 1895, the campus relocated to Waco, Texas, and in 1902, the university was renamed Texas Christian University. TCU maintains academic affiliations with several organizations, including Oak Ridge Associated Universities (ORAU), Consortium for North American Higher Education Collaboration (CONAHEC), Council of Independent Colleges (CIC), and the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities (NAICU). According to the U.S. News & World Report 2022, TCU is ranked #83 among National Universities and #1165 globally.

Campus, Infrastructure, and Academic Programs
Spanning 283 acres, TCU’s campus comprises eight colleges and schools, with a strong emphasis on a classical liberal arts education. The campus is organized into three main areas: academic, residential, and Worth Hills. University Drive, a scenic oak-lined street, divides the academic buildings, including the library and chapel on the east side, from the residential zones on the west. The university offers a comprehensive learning environment equipped with modern facilities to support student engagement. TCU provides 117 undergraduate, 65 graduate, and 38 doctoral programs. Popular undergraduate fields include business, communication, education, fine arts, liberal arts, nursing, and health sciences.

Achievements and Notable Alumni
The Neeley School of Business at TCU is recognized nationally, ranking #28 among undergraduate business schools by Bloomberg Businessweek. The university also hosts ROTC programs for both the U.S. Air Force (Detachment 845 "Flying Frogs") and the U.S. Army ("Horned Frog Battalion"), with about 3% of graduates commissioning as officers annually. Distinguished alumni include writer Richard J. Allen, actress Tudi Roche, bestselling author Dan Jenkins, and Robert J. McCann, CEO of UBS Group Americas.

Student Diversity and Corporate Connections
TCU enrolls over 10,000 students, including approximately 8,800 undergraduates and 580 international students. The campus maintains a male-to-female ratio of 41:59. The Office of Diversity & Inclusion, along with the DEI Department, actively promotes a more inclusive campus environment through expanded learning opportunities, mandatory training for selection committees, and integrating DEI competencies into the core curriculum. Major companies that regularly visit the university for recruitment and collaboration include IBM, Intel, JPMorgan Chase, KPMG, Insight Global, E&T Farms, and Fox Sports Southwest.

fields.name: Texas Tech University
fields.about:
Texas Tech University Overview

History & Affiliations:
Texas Tech University (TTU), founded in 1923 as Texas Technological College, is a public research university in Lubbock, Texas. It is the flagship of the Texas Tech University System. Accredited by the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools, TTU had the seventh-largest student enrollment in Texas as of Fall 2018. The Office of International Affairs supports its global mission. In 2022, US News ranked TTU 450th among Best Global Universities.

Campuses & Academics:
TTU’s main campus in Lubbock houses its graduate school, law school, and medical school—one of only two Texas universities with all three on one campus. The university offers over 150 degree programs through 13 schools and hosts 60 research centers. Since 1927, it has awarded more than 200,000 degrees, including 40,000+ graduate and professional degrees.

Research & Alumni:
TTU is classified as an R1 university for very high research activity, with strengths in epidemiology, wind energy, nanophononics, and more. Enrollment reached over 40,000 students by Fall 2020. The Texas Tech Alumni Association has over 27,000 members worldwide. Notable alumni include Demetrio B. Lakas (former President of Panama) and three U.S. governors.

Diversity & Enrollment:
Recognized as a Hispanic-Serving Institution, about 25% of undergraduates identify as Hispanic. TTU attracts students from all 50 states and over 100 countries. It is the largest university in West Texas, with steady enrollment growth aiming for 40,000 students by 2020. Since 1927, TTU has awarded over 173,000 bachelor's, 34,000 master's, 5,900 doctorates, and 7,000 law degrees.

fields.name: Texas Wesleyan University
fields.about:
History, Affiliations, and Rankings
Founded in 1870 by the Methodist Episcopal Church as Polytechnic College, Texas Wesleyan University evolved through reforms to become a university in 1934. The campus was established east of Fort Worth, on land donated by pioneers A.S. Hall, W.D. Hall, and George Tandy. It is affiliated with the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities and the International Association of Methodist-Related Schools. US News ranks it #299 nationally, while Times Higher Education places it between #601-800.

Campus, Programs, and Services
Located on a 75-acre campus in Fort Worth, Texas Wesleyan has five schools: Natural and Social Sciences, Nurse Anesthesia Graduate Programs, Business Administration, Arts & Letters, and Education. It offers over 30 undergraduate and graduate programs, with popular majors including Nursing Anesthesia, Business, Psychology, Accounting, Criminal Justice, and Counseling Psychology. Student services include tutoring, health care, career support, and campus safety features such as 24-hour patrols and escort services. Alcohol consumption is prohibited on campus for all students.

Achievements and Alumni
Texas Wesleyan has been accredited by the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools since becoming co-educational in 1935. Graduate programs in teaching and nurse anesthesia were added in the late 20th century. Notable alumni include table tennis player Biba Golic, Texas state representative Phil King, and basketball pro Ben Hunt.

Diversity and Career Support
The university embraces a diverse student body, including over 7% international students, across various backgrounds and identities. Texas Wesleyan offers career services like job fairs, employer events, and internship opportunities to help students launch their careers.

fields.name: The Australian College of Applied Professions
fields.about: The Australian College of Applied Professions (ACAP) was established with the mission to provide high-quality education in psychology, counseling, social work, and related applied professional fields. Since its inception, ACAP has grown to become one of Australia’s leading institutions specializing in applied social sciences and health disciplines. The college focuses on blending academic theory with practical experience, aiming to equip students with the skills needed to make a meaningful impact in their communities. Over the years, ACAP has expanded its campuses across multiple cities and developed a broad range of undergraduate and postgraduate programs to meet the evolving demands of professional practice in Australia.

fields.name: The Polytechnic University of Milan
fields.about:
The Polytechnic University of Milan, founded in 1863, is Italy’s leading technical university, specializing in engineering, architecture, and design. Originally named Istituto Tecnico Superiore, it began with civil and industrial engineering and later added architecture in 1865. The university’s main campus is located in Milan’s Città Studi district, where it moved in 1927. It also has campuses across Lombardy and Emilia-Romagna regions.

Consistently ranked among the world’s top technical universities, it placed 16th globally in QS’s 2020 rankings, with high marks in design and engineering fields. Notable alumni include Nobel laureate Giulio Natta and architect Renzo Piano. The historic campus buildings were designed by the university’s own graduates, reflecting its rich heritage.

fields.name: The University of Adelaide
fields.about:
History, Affiliations, and Rankings
Founded in 1874, the University of Adelaide is one of Australia’s oldest universities. It was the first Australian university to admit women in 1880 and the first to have a woman on its University Council. Accredited by AACSB and uniquely holding ACEEU dual accreditation as an Entrepreneurial and Engaged University, it ranks 108th in the QS World University Rankings 2022 and 111th in Times Higher Education 2022.

Campuses and Programs
The university operates four campuses: North Terrace (main campus in central Adelaide), Waite (plant and agricultural research), Roseworthy (north of Adelaide), and Melbourne (Docklands). It offers a wide range of courses across natural sciences, medicine, engineering, and social sciences, with notable strengths in petroleum engineering, dentistry, and veterinary science.

Achievements and Alumni
The University of Adelaide has produced 114 Rhodes Scholars and counts five Nobel Laureates among its faculty and alumni, including Nobel Prize winners Robin Warren and Barry Marshall for their discovery about peptic ulcers. Julia Gillard, Australia’s first female Prime Minister, is also an alumna.

Student Diversity and Career Opportunities
With over 22,000 students, including 9,000 international students from 100+ countries, the university boasts a balanced gender ratio and a diverse community. Graduates find opportunities with top employers like McKinsey, Goldman Sachs, Ernst & Young, and United Health Group.

fields.name: The University of British Columbia (UBC)
fields.about:
University of British Columbia (UBC): Overview

History & Rankings
Founded in 1908, the University of British Columbia (UBC) is one of Canada’s oldest and most prestigious universities. Initially affiliated with McGill University, UBC adopted McGill's curriculum and faculty in its early years. The university moved to its current Vancouver campus in 1925. Military training was once mandatory, and during WWII, thousands of UBC students joined the armed forces. UBC consistently ranks among the top global institutions, placing #37 (Times Higher Education 2022), #42 (Shanghai 2021), and #46 (QS 2022), and in the top 3 nationally.

Campuses & Programs
UBC has two main campuses: Vancouver and Okanagan, both situated in Point Grey with scenic surroundings. Key facilities include the Chan Centre, UBC Welcome Centre, and the Centre for Interactive Research in Sustainability. Major faculties include Arts, Dentistry, Law, and Science. UBC offers diverse programs at undergraduate, postgraduate, exchange, and distance-learning levels in areas such as Applied Science, Law, Medicine, Architecture, and Humanities.

Achievements & Alumni
UBC is a world leader in research and innovation, ranked among the top 20 public universities globally. It has received multiple awards for its continuing education and research excellence. UBC is also a leader in industry collaboration, with over 230 spin-off companies and a strong patent portfolio. Notable alumni include Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, former PM Kim Campbell, architect Arthur Erickson, and Nobel Laureate economist Robert Mundell.

Student Body & Diversity
UBC hosts over 48,000 students, including more than 16,000 international students. Nearly 44% of international students are of East Asian origin, and 37% speak English as their first language. The U.S. and China are the top sources of international enrolment. UBC's sprawling 988-acre campus makes it one of Canada's largest universities.

fields.name: Selkirk College
fields.about:
History, Affiliations & Rankings
Founded in 1965, Selkirk College is British Columbia's oldest rural community college. It opened in 1966 in Castlegar with 458 students across four programs. Now a fully accredited public institution, it is affiliated with Colleges and Institutes Canada, the Canadian Bureau for International Education, and other national bodies. Selkirk holds a global Webometrics ranking of #8104, #1933 in continental rankings, and #111 in Canada.

Campuses, Programs & Facilities
Selkirk College operates six campuses in the West Kootenay and Boundary regions, including its main campus in Castlegar. It offers over 60 nationally recognized programs to 2,800+ full-time students annually, covering certificates, diplomas, bachelor's degrees, co-op, and continuing education. Small class sizes promote personalized learning.

Achievements & Alumni
Selkirk alumni are excelling globally. Wesley Fakrogha credits his Business Diploma for launching his business, while filmmaker Lynn Trinh says the college helped her grow as an artist and connect with peers who are now industry colleagues.

Student Life & Diversity
With 17 student clubs, Selkirk embraces diversity in all forms—cultural, religious, gender, and more. The college frequently hosts webinars, seminars, and recruitment events to support student career development.

fields.name: The University of Chicago
fields.about:
The University of Chicago: A Global Hub for Innovation

Founded in 1890, the University of Chicago is a prestigious private research university known for shaping influential leaders, including CEOs, U.S. presidents, attorneys, authors, astronauts, and 92 Nobel Prize winners. Recognized as one of the world’s top institutions, it has a strong global presence with centers in cities like Delhi, Hong Kong, London, Beijing, and Paris.

The university offers over 150 graduate programs across diverse fields and conducts cutting-edge research through its national and affiliated labs. Notable achievements include pioneering the link between genetics and cancer.

Beyond academics, UChicago supports student life with more than 400 clubs and organizations. It is also committed to educational equity, offering a wide range of scholarships and financial aid to support talented students from all backgrounds.

fields.about:
University of Findlay Overview

History & Rankings:
Founded in 1882 as Findlay College by the City of Findlay and the Churches of God General Conference, it became the University of Findlay in 1989. It is affiliated with the Great Midwest Athletic Conference and NCAA Division II. In 2022, Times Higher Education ranked it above 600 in the U.S., while U.S. News & World Report ranked it #263 among National Universities.

Campus & Academics:
Located in Findlay, Ohio, the university features a red-brick campus and the Mazza Museum, home to the largest U.S. collection of children’s book illustrations. It offers standout programs like English and Western equestrian studies, and includes colleges of Business, Education, Health Professions, Pharmacy, Sciences, and Arts, Humanities & Social Sciences.

Recognition & Alumni:
Named a top Midwest institution by The Princeton Review and recognized by The Wall Street Journal and College Factual. Notable alumni include U.S. Representatives R. Clint Cole and Ralph D. Cole, and fashion model Joanie Dodds.

Student Life & Career Services:
International students make up about 5.4% of the student body. With around 100 student organizations, students engage in academics, service, media, arts, and Greek life. Career services assist with resumes, internships, and interview prep.

Seneca has multiple campuses across the Greater Toronto Area, including Newnham (one of Canada’s largest), King, Markham, Peterborough, Yorkgate, and Seneca Downtown. It offers over 180 programs and 500+ career pathways in areas like business, hospitality, engineering, health sciences, and the arts.

Seneca’s Esthetician program received the 2011 Excellence in Education Award from Leading Spas of Canada. The college supports diversity and inclusion, highlighted by alumni like Ms. Sandiford Day, an advocate for equity in STEM. fields.name: The University of Melbourne
fields.about:
University of Melbourne Overview

History & Rankings:
Founded in 1853, the University of Melbourne is Victoria’s oldest and Australia’s second-oldest university. Originally offering degrees in Arts, Medicine, Law, and Music, it’s now a global leader in education and research. It is a member of prestigious groups like the Group of Eight, Universities 21, and the Association of Commonwealth Universities. Ranked #25 by U.S. News, #33 by Times Higher Education, and #37 by QS in 2022.

Campuses & Courses:
The university has 7 campuses across Victoria, with its main campus in Parkville. It also part-owns the Melbourne Business School. Students can choose from 100+ study areas and tailor their degrees across disciplines—from Law and Commerce to Music and Medicine. Programs range from undergraduate to postgraduate, research degrees, micro-credentials, and professional development.

Achievements & Alumni:
Known for academic excellence, Melbourne has produced Nobel laureates, prime ministers, and global leaders. Notable alumni include Nobel Prize winner Elizabeth Blackburn, former Prime Ministers Julia Gillard, Harold Holt, and Robert Menzies, and actor Randeep Hooda. The university also contributes to major research initiatives, including global health projects like BIANCO.

Diversity & Industry Connections:
Over 20,000 international students from 100+ countries enroll annually. The university supports diversity through initiatives like the Athena SWAN Bronze Award for gender equality in STEMM. With 430,000+ alumni worldwide and 1,600+ industry partners, graduates enjoy strong employability with top recruiters like Deloitte, EY, McKinsey, BCG, and Johnson & Johnson.

fields.name: The University of Newcastle (Australia)
fields.about:
University of Newcastle Overview

History & Rankings:
Established in 1951 as a college of the University of New South Wales, the University of Newcastle became independent in 1965. Its main campus is in Callaghan, NSW, with additional campuses in Ourimbah, Port Macquarie, Singapore, Newcastle city, and Sydney. The Newcastle Business School holds AACSB accreditation, and its marketing and HR programs are accredited by Australian professional bodies. The university ranks #197 in QS World University Rankings 2022 and falls within #251–300 in THE rankings.

Campuses & Courses:
The university has five campuses, with the largest at Callaghan, spread over 346 acres of natural bushland. Ourimbah Campus collaborates with local institutes offering joint programs. Sydney Campus caters to international students, while the Port Macquarie Campus focuses on postgraduate and research programs. The Singapore campus, opened in 2006, is the university’s first international branch. Key study areas include Education, Social Sciences, STEMM, Nursing, and Health.

Research & Alumni:
The university is highly rated for research quality, receiving top ‘5’ ratings across 22 fields in the Excellence in Research for Australia (ERA) assessment. It ranks 8th nationally for research rated ‘well above world standard.’ In STEMM disciplines, 100% of research meets or exceeds global standards. The university is also recognized for social impact, ranking 68th globally in reducing inequality. Notable alumni include actor-comedian Steve Abbott and theatre director David Berthold.

Student Body & Industry Links:
With over 39,000 students (including 7,500+ international students) and 1,100 staff, the university supports a diverse academic community. It has held the Employer of Choice for Gender Equality accreditation for over a decade. Major recruiters include Deloitte, Automotive Holdings Group, and Newcastle Permanent Building Society.

fields.name: The University of Queensland
fields.about:
History, Affiliations, and Rankings
The University of Queensland (UQ) was founded in 1909 and began teaching in 1911 in Brisbane. It is affiliated with the Group of Eight, Universitas 21, ASAIHL, EdX, and McDonnell International Scholars Academy. UQ consistently ranks among the top global universities, placed #47 by QS, #54 by THE, and #36 by US News in 2022, and ranks 3rd to 5th in Australia.

Campuses, Facilities, and Courses
UQ has three Queensland campuses: St. Lucia, Gatton, and Herston. It features Queensland’s largest research library, museums, theatres, college residences, and extensive sports facilities. The university offers about 390 undergraduate and postgraduate programs across fields such as Arts, Engineering, Health, Law, Sciences, Education, Psychology, and Business.

Achievements and Alumni
With over 280,000 graduates, including 15,400 PhDs, UQ ranks highly in scientific research—#4 globally for Environment and Ecology and #2 for Agriculture (NTU 2021). It has received numerous national teaching awards. Notable alumni include Quentin Bryce, Peter Beattie, and Geoffrey Rush.

Diversity and Student Life
UQ hosts over 55,300 students from 142 countries, supported by 3,513 faculty and staff from over 200 nationalities speaking 220 languages. Nearly 200 student clubs foster a vibrant campus life. The university is ranked #63 worldwide in the 2022 QS Graduate Employability Rankings.

fields.name: Seton Hall University
fields.about:
History, Affiliations, and Rankings
Seton Hall University (SHU), located in South Orange, New Jersey, is a private Catholic research institution and the oldest diocesan university in the United States. Founded in 1856 by Bishop James Roosevelt Bayley and named after his aunt, Saint Elizabeth Ann Seton, the university maintains strong religious ties to Catholicism. Academically, it is affiliated with the Association of Catholic Colleges and Universities (ACCU), the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities (NAICU), and the Space Grant Consortium. In athletics, Seton Hall competes in NCAA Division I as a member of the Big East Conference and ACHA: CSCHC. In 2022, it was ranked 237 in the U.S. by Times Higher Education and 127th in the U.S. News & World Report's National Universities ranking.

Campus, Infrastructure, and Academic Offerings
Seton Hall's campus is located in a suburban setting just 30 minutes from New York City. It comprises 11 colleges and schools with a total enrollment of approximately 5,800 undergraduate and 4,400 graduate students. The university offers a wide range of academic programs including undergraduate, graduate, online, dual degree, certificate, and continuing education options. Popular majors include Biology, Humanities, Finance, Nursing, International Relations, Business, Marketing, Health Professions, Social Sciences, Accounting, Education, Engineering, and Information Technology. Students have access to comprehensive support services such as health and counseling services, career resources, and educational opportunity programs.

Achievements and Notable Alumni
Seton Hall has received an A+ rating from U.S. News & World Report for its appeal to B students and is recognized among America’s Best Colleges. Specific program rankings include 85th for part-time MBA, 17th for online graduate nursing, 62nd for master's in nursing, and 73rd for doctor of nursing practice. Distinguished alumni include Jesse Bright (Credentialing Coordinator, The Valley Hospital), Lisa Candella (Broker Associate, Berkshire Hathaway), Kimberly A. Capadona (Attorney, Archer & Greiner, P.C.), and Richard Dooley (Financial Advisor, First Allied Advisory Services).

Student Diversity and Recruitment
Seton Hall enrolls over 10,000 students from 46 U.S. states and 51 countries, with a student body that is 47% male and 53% female. International students make up about 5% of the population. The university emphasizes inclusion, diversity, and ethical development through its Office of Student Affairs. Leading employers who recruit from Seton Hall include Hackensack Meridian Health, Verizon, Prudential Financial, Merck, Rutgers University, EY, Johnson & Johnson, Novartis, Morgan Stanley, Deloitte, JPMorgan Chase, Bristol Myers Squibb, ADP, and Amazon.

fields.name: The University of Scranton
fields.about:
History, Affiliations, and Rankings
Founded in 1888 by Bishop William O’Hara, the University of Scranton transitioned to Jesuit management in 1942. It’s affiliated with AJCU, ACCU, NAICU, and CIC. U.S. News ranks Scranton 6th among master’s universities in the North and highlights its strong undergraduate programs in business, engineering, and nursing.

Campus, Facilities, and Programs
Scranton offers solid student services, including tutoring, health, daycare, and 24-hour safety patrols. About 20% of students have cars on campus, and alcohol is allowed for legal-age students. The university offers 65 undergraduate majors and 29 graduate programs, ranging from Accounting to Theology.

Athletics and Alumni
Scranton supports 23 NCAA Division III sports and a variety of intramural activities. Notable alumni include writer Susan Campbell Bartoletti, politician Joseph Battisto, and Pennsylvania official Richard J. Beamish.

Student Diversity and Employers
The student body is predominantly White, with limited racial diversity. Leading employers like Aramark, Comcast, and Communications Construction Group regularly recruit from Scranton.

fields.name: Sheridan College Davis
fields.about:
Sheridan College operates across three campuses: Davis, Trafalgar, and Hazel McCallion. The Davis Campus, located in Brampton, is the largest, hosting approximately 13,300 of the college’s 26,800 full-time and part-time students. In addition, around 16,950 students are enrolled in continuing and professional education programs across all campuses.

Demonstrating its global appeal, Sheridan College welcomes over 6,800 international students from more than 80 countries, with many studying at the Davis Campus. To support this diverse and dynamic student population, the college employs a team of approximately 3,700 full-time and part-time faculty, researchers, and support staff.

Sheridan offers programs through five key academic faculties:

Faculty of Animation, Arts and Design

Pilon School of Business

Faculty of Applied Science and Technology

Faculty of Applied Health and Community Studies

Faculty of Humanities and Social Sciences

It also has dedicated departments for continuing and professional studies. The Davis Campus houses all of these faculties except the Faculty of Animation, Arts and Design, which is based at another location. Programs offered at the Davis Campus include those in Engineering and Technology, Applied Health, and Community Services.

The campus is also home to cutting-edge research centres in areas such as music, mobile innovation, and advanced manufacturing, reinforcing Sheridan’s commitment to applied learning and industry collaboration.

fields.name: SKEMA Business School
fields.about:
History & Rankings
Founded in 2009 from the merger of Ceram Business School (Sophia Antipolis) and ESC Lille, SKEMA is a private, non-profit business school in France. The name SKEMA combines the Greek "skhêma" (shape) and stands for "School of Knowledge Economy and Management." It holds prestigious accreditations including AACSB, AMBA, EQUIS, CGE, and recognition from the Chinese Ministry of Education and the GAC. SKEMA ranks #21 globally and #6 in France for its Master in Management program (QS 2022).

Campuses & Programs
SKEMA has 9 campuses across 7 countries including France, Brazil, China, the U.S., and South Africa, with offices in Canada and India. Its campuses are located in innovation hubs, fostering strong industry ties. It offers undergraduate programs in International Business and Global Management, 19 MSc degrees, 4 PhD programs, Executive MBAs, and summer courses in Paris. Fields of study include Business, Data Science, Digital Marketing, AI/ML, Finance, Entrepreneurship, Supply Chain, Hospitality, Fashion, and more.

Partnerships & Alumni
The school partners with over 100 global universities and 2,500 companies, offering internships and job placements. With 70+ student clubs and 45,000 alumni worldwide, notable graduates include Prince Joel David Makonnen and Jean-Philippe Courtois (Microsoft).

Student Life & Opportunities
SKEMA hosts 8,500 students and 160 faculty from 120+ countries. About 35% of students are international. Its Talent & Careers center facilitates over 10,000 job offers annually. Companies like Chanel, Coca-Cola, L'Oréal, Accenture, and Samsung regularly recruit from the school.

fields.name: The University of Texas at Arlington
fields.about: The University of Texas at Arlington (UTA) is a public research university in Arlington, Texas. Established in 1895 as Arlington College, it joined the University of Texas System in 1967. UTA offers more than 180 degree programs across 10 colleges, including Business, Engineering, Nursing, and Science. It is especially recognized for its programs in aerospace, biotechnology, and data science.

fields.name: Slippery Rock University
fields.about:
Slippery Rock University (SRU) is a public, four-year institution located in Slippery Rock, Pennsylvania. Established in 1889 as Slippery Rock Normal School, it originally focused on teacher training. The university began offering bachelor’s and master’s degrees in 1960 and is now part of Pennsylvania’s State System of Higher Education. SRU is accredited by the Middle States Commission on Higher Education, ensuring its academic standards meet national benchmarks. The university is ranked #600 in the U.S. College Rankings 2022 and #78 by U.S. News & World Report, making it a reputable choice for higher education in the United States.

The SRU campus spans 660 acres in the scenic rolling hills of western Pennsylvania, about 60 miles north of Pittsburgh. It is also within travel distance of major destinations like New York City, Niagara Falls, Philadelphia, and Washington, D.C. The campus features modern classrooms, residence halls, academic departments, administrative buildings, and over 160 student clubs, covering interests from academics and performing arts to journalism, cultural groups, and Greek life. SRU also supports 17 NCAA Division II sports teams—10 for women and 7 for men. Academically, the university offers more than 150 undergraduate programs, 40 master’s degrees, and a variety of certificate and online learning options.

Slippery Rock University continues to grow in popularity, particularly for its programs in business, music, education, and physical therapy. Its business school has earned praise for its quality, and the university is known for providing a solid academic foundation that is challenging yet manageable. Prominent alumni include Matt Adams (professional baseball player), Janet Anderson (professional golfer), and Cheryl Bailey (former GM of the U.S. Women’s National Soccer Team and commissioner of the National Women’s Soccer League).

Diversity is a core value at SRU. The university enrolls over 8,800 students, including around 7,300 undergraduates and 1,400 graduate students, supported by a faculty of more than 860. Students come from 41 U.S. states and 34 countries, contributing to a vibrant and inclusive campus environment. The gender distribution is fairly balanced, with 44% male and 56% female students. SRU graduates are sought after by leading employers such as Kforce Inc., Mutual Mobile, and UPMC, reflecting the school’s strong career support and industry connections.

fields.name: The University of Texas at Austin
fields.about:
History, Affiliations, and Rankings
The University of Texas at Austin, founded in 1883, is a leading public research university located in Texas’ capital. It began with one building, eight faculty, and 221 students and now has 18 colleges serving about 51,000 students. UT Austin ranks among the top 40 universities worldwide, with strong national rankings (#29 US, QS 2023 #72 global). It is accredited by SACSCOC to award degrees at all levels.

Campus, Facilities, and Programs
The campus spans over 1,400 acres, including the main campus in central Austin and research facilities elsewhere in Texas. With 150 buildings, numerous museums, libraries, and centers, the university offers a vibrant student experience. UT Austin provides over 170 undergraduate majors across 13 colleges and more than 230 graduate programs, including 98 doctoral degrees.

Achievements and Alumni
UT Austin leads in NSF-funded research, receiving over $796 million in sponsored projects (2019-20) and ranking first in the US for NSF research support. The university boasts 53 national championships, 517 conference titles, and 130 Olympic medals. Its alumni network of over 482,000 includes prominent figures in business, politics, arts, and more.

Student Diversity and Career Opportunities
In fall 2020, UT enrolled about 40,000 undergraduates with a diverse student body from all 50 states and 123 countries. Around 8% live on campus, and nearly 1,000 student organizations support a wide range of cultures and interests. Graduates often work at major companies like Apple, Boeing, NASA, Deloitte, SpaceX, and government agencies.
